column5: We have this poster in our library at the school I work in!

Ah, the truth comes out!

When we closed back in March (and thought it would only be a couple weeks), the idea was thrown out. It makes sense to meâ€”-I work in a school with ages 3-7, and they are tiny germ factories. I wouldnâ€™t be happy that my carpeted room would be covered in spilled milk and crumbs, but what can you do? I donâ€™t want to be the asshole that says no when they just have our safety in mind.

(Also just to add on, we donâ€™t get lunch breaks. The only break we do get nap time but the kids are in the room.)
Awesome. I canâ€™t wait to teach 4 year olds the rules of the classroom by Zoom because we canâ€™t go back to work in August.
The silence is deafening.

https://www.dmv.org/ky-kentucky/replace-license.php#Replace-a-KY-Drivers-License
Iâ€™m in middle Georgia and ran into to Kroger today. Most people had on masks, including employees.

Iâ€™ve been teaching from home and was struggling too. I started following a person named Lorenzo (on instagram and tik tok) and they are a PhD student that is huge on making goals. So I started making a list of morning goals and afternoon goals that I needed to get done that day. Itâ€™s been super helpful because I donâ€™t have to stick to a strict schedule (except meetings) as long as I get my goals done for the day.
We donâ€™t graduate in Georgia Pre-K because too many graduations make the real one when their seniors less special and important. Thatâ€™s what I was told anyway.

We shouldnâ€™t be opening until June. Iâ€™m lucky that I am a teacher and can work from home. However,  I am very concerned for my brother and dad and not only getting sick themselves but bringing the virus home to my mom. 

My county has sent a letter to the governor petitioning for the closures to stay in place. Our health department is not prepared for an onslaught of testing. Many of our restaurants are not opening and only continuing with curbside service.

I know this isnâ€™t an easy decision but this should be data based. People are going to get sick and possibly die.

If you feel like shit/look like shit/are having a shitty day, go talk to a Pre-K kid. They will tell you youâ€™re beautiful even with those coffee stains on your shirt and the hair you havenâ€™t washed in 4 days.
Iâ€™ve had to ask them to STOP LICKING THE BOTTOM OF THEIR SHOES.

I like your positivity!

Ok, the documents are [here.](https://www.gapsc.com/CurrentEducator/takeCareYourCertificate/RenewCertificate.aspx)  Click the top
one(if thatâ€™s what applies to you) and scroll down to the bottom. Those are what Iâ€™ve filled out to renew before.

It says Employer must request renewal, but maybe if you start the paperwork it will get the ball rolling.

Hey, fellow Georgia teacher here. First off, Iâ€™d check to make sure your certificate is about to expire. You can do that at gapsc [here.](https://www.gapsc.com/Certification/Lookup.aspx) 

Check the date. It is supposed to be 5 yearsâ€”look at the expiration date.

I also have good and bad days. Today was good, but yesterday was rough. I cried off and on between Zoom meetings and snuck out to Dairy Queen for icecream. 

Something that has helped me(besides meds) is taking a walk. I go before and sometimes after (if the day is bad) contract hours and crank up the soundtrack to a broadway musical. It helps some.
I only have 18 kids, so it wasnâ€™t a big deal. If I had over 100, I wouldnâ€™t have done it.

I teach littles. I sent post cards, one packet to everyone, and an extra packet and crayons to a boy that does not have a computer. 

I donâ€™t know what you want me to tell you. I felt like they needed to know I was still there for them.
Is that just one ferret???
Itâ€™s ok to have your opinion. I accept that. My students know I love them. I show them affection. But they also need to learn boundaries.

The stopping the greeting and waving was because of COVID and we had a stomach bug going around school too.

The other part isnâ€™t too much. Itâ€™s never too young to talk to kids about touching. For example, if one of them is poking someone and the kid tells them to stop, they need to stop. If they donâ€™t want to be touched they have every right to tell them no. Plus, it also teaches the other kid that no means no.

I did something similar with my Pre-K babies. Around the end of February I stopped and we just waved.

I always include a non-touching choice. I donâ€™t like to be touched and I want to give them the power to say no touching. ğŸ¤·ğŸ»â€â™€ï¸

Really it can be rewarding. Be picky about the school and the admin, they make a huge difference. You could try subbing at different schools and see what you like.

Similar thing happened two years ago when a tropical depression knocked out power for two weeks to several of our schoolsâ€”we didnâ€™t make any days up because it was a called a state of emergency.

Friday was better, but only because this is week is spring break so I donâ€™t have any requirements.

I had way too much screen time this week.
I sent my Pre-Kers a cardâ€”just told them I missed them, hope they liked their lessons online, and to stay safe.

Weâ€™re out until the end of April. I teach Georgia Pre-K. We are focusing on essential standardsâ€”what gets them ready for Kindergarten. Using a mixture of handouts, google slide games, Class Dojo, Zoom, and Smart Tech Learnibg Suite. No assignments, no grades.
Itâ€™s not required, but my issue is that I teach Pre-K and they canâ€™t have more than an hour screen time a day (state rules).

I teach Georgia Pre-K. Iâ€™m concerned too that if it keeps spreading in Georgia the way it has in the last couple weeks (from less than 100 to over 1000 cases in 2 weeks) we wonâ€™t go back. My anxiety level  is through the roof. I miss my kids and my classroom. I miss my co-workers.
Itâ€™s so scary. I hope her family recovers and yours stays safe!
